StandardDialog.Name: Dialog1
StandardDialog.DialogHeader: Raising Concerns Through Our Formal Complaint Process

QuizDialog.Name: QDialog1
QuizDialog.DialogBody: A local government official mentions that youâ€™d be more likely to get a contract if you hired his son as a representative. Do you think you should hire him?

Rules.Rule: Correct. Our anti-corruption policy prohibits anyone in the organization from making bribes of any kind, anywhere in the world. In this case, the job could be considered an improper payment.

Dialogs.BookmarkDialog:
Resume course

Hello,

Since this is not the first time you have opened the course, we have restored you to the page you were last on.

Click the "Resume" button to continue from where you left off, or the "Restart" button to start from the beginning.

Restart

Resume

Page.Name: Introduction
Page.Text: In the war against cybercrime, the hackers appear to be winning.

It seems as if every day there is news of another massive data breach that was discovered only after millions of individuals’ private and financial information was stolen and then likely bought and sold through an underground black market.

Besides the cash they reap from the stolen information obtained during a breach, cybercriminals are after trade secrets, insider information, and access to other areas of a secured network that may prove profitable for their criminal organizations.
Once they’re in, they can install malware that evades detection and lies in wait for other users to logon so they can steal their passwords.

In addition to traditional schemes to get your password, such as phishing and social engineering, cybercriminals now have a new weapon to add to their arsenal of attacks, and this one could prove to be harmful and even fatal to those who fall victim to it.

For the first time in history, hackers have crossed over from the virtual realm into the physical world and have begun hacking into cars, baby monitors, security cameras, and most alarmingly, implanted healthcare devices, such as pacemakers and defibrillators.
Once they have breached such a device, they can remotely control its functions, alter its programming or disable it altogether and demand a ransom to return control to its rightful owner.

Thousands of these products make new connections to the web every day and collectively become part of what’s known as the “Internet of Things,” or IOT, which will surpass 75 billion such devices within a decade.

What’s more, hacking into an IOT device can be done with relative ease. Lax security controls set forth by manufacturers and an absence of agreed-upon security standards across the industry combine to make for easy hacking of these products.

The implications for this type of attack are staggering and underscore the need to develop a security-conscience culture made up of individuals who have been trained to detect, defend, and recover from cyber-attacks both at home and in the workplace.

Stage.Element:
About this Course

This short security awareness course covers the key security best practices you should follow so that you can prevent, detect, and respond to information security incidents.

At the end of this course is a final exam, which you must pass to receive course credit.

What Is

Information Security?

Information security encompasses all the ways in which we protect our information assets and capabilities from unauthorized access, modification, or destruction and other forms of attack.

Essentially, it is how we defend our computer systems and all of our valuable information in digital or hardcopy format, which in today's Information Age is absolutely critical to our organization.
Personally Identifiable Information
Types of Private Data
Safeguarding Private Data

Interactivity:

Privacy

Ensuring the security of information allows us to ensure the privacy of information, meaning that it is not exposed to the public or attackers. Click each icon to learn more about privacy.

Personally Identifiable Information

Personally Identifiable Information (PII) is defined as any information that permits the identity of an individual to be directly or indirectly inferred. For example, a government issued ID number will directly identify an individual and is PII. But enough indirect information to identify an individual (e.g. date of birth, place of birth, gender, race, etc.) is also considered PII, even if each piece of information by itself does not identify an individual.

Close

Types of Private Data

PII, medical records, and personal financial information are the most common types of private data you may have access to. If you are uncertain whether or not some of the information you handle is private, ask your supervisor.

Close

Safeguarding Private Data

Digital private data should always be password protected and encrypted when it is stored or transmitted. Encryption is a way of scrambling data so that only someone with an appropriate key can read it. Hardcopy private data should always be stored under lock and key.

Close

Threats

To secure our information and ensure privacy, we first have to understand the threats we face.

A threat is a person, circumstance, or event that could harm our information assets or infrastructure or violate our physical security controls.

Interactivity:

Typical Threats

To learn more about typical threats you may face, click each item.

Social Engineering

When attempting to steal information or a person’s identity, a malicious hacker will often try to trick you into giving out sensitive information rather than actually breaking into your computer. This is called social engineering and is often done over the phone.

Close

Phishing

Phishers typically create fake emails that appear to come from someone you trust, such as a bank, credit card company, or a popular website. The email may ask you to “confirm your account details” and direct you to a website that looks just like the real website, but whose sole purpose is stealing information.

Of course, if you enter your information, a cybercriminal could use it to steal your identity and possibly make fraudulent purchases with your money.

Close

Malware

Malicious software, or malware, is any program that seeks to do harm or steal information.

Close

Data Thieves

Could someone be walking out the door with an internal database stored on a Micro SD card or USB drive? Could someone be taking pictures of sensitive information or items with a smartphone? Unfortunately the answer is yes. Be vigilant, protecting any sensitive information you manage from these devices.

Close
Viruses and Worms
Ransomware
Trojan Horses

Interactivity:

Malware Examples

Click on each item to learn more about the most common forms of malware.

Viruses and Worms

A virus is a malicious program that can “infect” other programs, carry out some mission, such as deleting files or stealing information, and self-replicate.

A worm is similar to a virus, but it is a program in and of itself and does not need to infect another program. It can also replicate itself over a network without any user interaction.

Close

Ransomware

Ransomware is a type of malware that restricts a user’s access to systems or files, typically by encryption, and then demands a ransom to restore access.

Often, systems are infected by ransomware through a link in a bogus email. When the user clicks the link, the ransomware is downloaded to the user’s computer, smartphone, or other device. Most ransomware will also spread through any connected network, encrypting files and rendering them unreadable.

Recently, ransomware attacks have been on the rise. In 2016, nearly 50% of organizations were hit with ransomware. In a recent case at a Los Angeles hospital, ransomware made patient files and other administrative functions inaccessible to hospital staff. The hacker demanded the Bitcoin equivalent of 17,000 USD to unlock their files. And the hospital decided it had no choice but to pay the ransom.

Close

Trojan Horses

Trojan Horse is the term used for any program with something malicious hidden inside, such as a virus or worm. Most malware uses the Trojan horse technique to trick you into installing a malicious program.

Close

Page.Name: Question 1

Elements.Intro:
Challenge

Questions

To apply what you've learned so far, please answer the following questions.

Note: iPad and Android users should touch each item twice
Elements.Element:
Question 1 of 12

Challenge Question

Which of the following is an example of PII?

Options.Option: Your Bank Account Number.
Office financial records.
Strategies, plans, and internal processes.
Encrypted files.

Page.Answer:
Correct

Your Bank Account Number can be used to personally identify you.

CONTINUE
Please try again.
Please try again.
Please try again.

Page.Name: Question 2

Elements.Element:
Question 2 of 12

Challenge Question

Which of the following is a true statement?

Options.Option: Hackers use ransomware to encrypt files and make the user pay a ransom to regain access.
Hackers use ransomware to slow your system by flooding your browser with adware.

Page.Answer:
Correct

Hackers encrypt files and demand a “ransom” from the user to unlock the files.

CONTINUE
Please try again.

Stage.Element:
Best Practices:

Safe Computing

Hackers and cybercriminals target end-users because they have the login credentials, access rights, and information they’re after, such as internal confidential or trade secret information. They may also be after your bank account or credit card information, which could be used to steal money or make fraudulent purchases in your name.

The good news is there are lots of things you can do to prevent security incidents and protect your identity.

Password Phrases

It can be very difficult to remember strong passwords. However, you can also use long phrases, such as “I have 1 aunt, 3 brothers, 2 sisters, and 1 dog.”

The longer the password is, the longer it takes a password cracker to crack the password.

PASSWORD
Ihave1dog.
Ihave2sisters.
Ihave2sistersand1dog.

LENGTH OF TIME TO CRACK
6 days
16,000,000 years
99,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 years

Best Practices:

Password

First of all, to help secure our network and your own identity, you should create a strong password, and keep it secret.

Additionally, your passwords should:
Be as long as possible.
Not contain easily guessed personal information, such as your birthday or the name of your pet.
Not be written down or shared with anyone.
Be changed immediately if there is any reason to believe it has been compromised.

Unique Passwords

Did you know that most web users use the same password for online banking as they do for all of their other accounts, such as email and social media? That means that if their email password was stolen, the thief could also steal from their bank account.

To help prevent this:

A good way to easily manage multiple, strong passwords is to use Password Management software (Ex. Dashlane, LastPass). These programs make the creation and management of multiple strong passwords easy and secure while allowing you to only have to remember one “master password”.
Use a unique password at work.
Use a separate, unique password for online banking.
Use at least one other separate, unique password for other systems.

Page.Name: Question 3

Elements.Intro:
Challenge

Questions

To apply what you've learned so far, please answer the following question.

Note: iPad and Android users should touch each item twice
Elements.Element:
Question 3 of 12

Challenge Question

Who do you think you should share your password with?

Options.Option: Just those you trust
No one

Page.Answer: Please try again.

Correct

You shouldn’t share your password with anyone.

CONTINUE

Stage.Element:
Best Practices:

For Avoiding Malware

Avoiding malware is another important way to protect our information resources.

There are, of course, many defenses (antivirus, firewalls, etc.) in place to protect you from malware but these tools cannot protect you if you unwittingly cooperate with malware:
Think before you click. Delete suspicious emails without opening them, such as those from unknown users with attachments.
If you don’t really need certain browser plugins, like JAVA, Flash, or Acrobat, disable them to prevent malware infections.

Best Practices:

For Avoiding Malware
If you think your computer does not have an up to date operating system or antivirus or antispyware program or is infected by malware, report it immediately.
Only install approved applications to avoid accidentally installing malware.
Avoid clicking on ads on websites. Browse instead to the official website for the vendor.

Page.Name: Question 4

Elements.Intro:
Challenge

Questions

To apply what you've learned so far, please answer the following question.

Note: iPad and Android users should touch each item twice
Elements.Element:
Question 4 of 12

Challenge Question

Identify which of the following at work scenarios are best practices or not:

Installing an application you find on the Internet.

Options.Option: Best Practice
Not a Best Practice

Page.Answer: Please try again.

Correct

You should only install approved applications.

CONTINUE

Page.Name: Best Practices for Thwarting Social Engineers

Stage.Element:
Best Practices:

For Thwarting Social Engineers

Social engineers are experts at deception.

To thwart social engineers:
Verify the identity of those who ask for sensitive information in person or over the phone before you release it.
Do not give out information about other employees, remote network access, organizational practices, or strategies to any unknown individual.

If you think you are the victim of social engineering, gather as much information as you can, such as the person’s name, telephone number, and what they are asking for and immediately report the incident.

Page.Name: Question 5

Elements.Intro:
Challenge

Questions

To apply what you've learned so far, please answer the following questions.

Note: iPad and Android users should touch each item twice
Elements.Element:
Question 5 of 12

Challenge Question

As you’re walking into a building, someone in uniform approaches you and says he’s collecting all ID badges because new ones will be arriving tomorrow. What do you think you should do?

Options.Option: Ask your supervisor about it before taking action.
Give him your badge.

Page.Answer:
Correct

Hackers often use social engineering techniques to gain access, bit by bit, to an organization. Getting access badges is often a first step and posing as a fellow employee is not uncommon.

CONTINUE
Please try again.

Page.Name: Question 6

Elements.Element:
Question 6 of 12

Challenge Question

You notice someone waiting outside of a secure area as you unlock the door. He smiles, approaches you, introduces himself as Sam, and asks your name. He says he’s lost his keys. Should you let him in?

Options.Option: Yes
No

Page.Answer: Please try again.

Correct

Simply apologize and offer to contact security to help him. They can decide if he should be allowed in.

CONTINUE

Page.Name: Question 7

Elements.Element:
Question 7 of 12

Challenge Question

Even though you didn’t let Sam in, someone else did, and you see him in the office an hour later. You overhear Sam asking a coworker for her username and password to install an upgrade. Is this suspicious?

Options.Option: Yes
No

Page.Answer:
Correct

You should never give your username or password to anyone and never give sensitive information to anyone until you’ve verified their identity, access rights, and need to know.

CONTINUE
Please try again.

Page.Name: Best Practices for Thwarting Internet Phishers

Stage.Element:
Best Practices:

For Thwarting Internet Phishers

To thwart Internet Phishers, follow these best practices:
Never respond to unsolicited email messages that request personal information. A reputable organization will never ask for your password or other sensitive information via email.
Be suspicious of emails that don’t address you by name or that have misspellings or simply don’t look professional.
Always navigate to your bank or other website by typing in the website address, rather than clicking a link from an email message.

Page.Name: Best Practices for Thwarting Internet Phishers (Cont’d)

Stage.Element:
Best Practices:

For Thwarting Internet Phishers

Dear Bank User: We have detected some unusual activity. We urgently ask you to follow the account review link: http://bit.do/bank
Keep in mind that fraudulent phishing messages can also be sent via SMS text messages, faxes, and even automated voice response systems.

Be aware that phishing emails may not always be designed to steal your information. Instead, their goal may be to install malicious software on your computer. This can happen by simply clicking an infected link or opening an infected attachment.

Spear Phishing

Phishers usually send their fake messages to any email address they can find. But these attempts are much more successful when they target a select group, or a few individuals, with a highly tailored message. This is known as spear phishing and is much harder to counter because the messages can seem so authentic.

For example, an attacker could conduct an online search, quickly compiling a list of names, email addresses, and job titles. The attacker can then send out an email message that appears to be coming from a colleague, discussing a relevant topic. This makes it much harder to resist opening an infected attachment or clicking on an infected link.

Thwart Spear

Phishing Attacks

To thwart spear phishing attacks:
If a suspicious looking email arrives from someone you trust, call them or email them separately and ask if they sent it before opening the email, clicking on any links, or opening any attachments.
Keep in mind that anything you’ve posted on social networks can be used in spear phishing emails to make them seem legitimate.

Business Email

Compromise (BEC)

A scam that has been on the rise recently is called Business Email Compromise or BEC. Typically, this involves a cybercriminal posing as an executive or manager and sending emails to employees requesting funds to be transferred or confidential data (W-2s, PII, etc.) provided. Many times, these communications are sent through “spoofed” email addresses that resemble the actual email address of the person they are posing as. They may even hijack the actual email account of the executive or manager, making it much more difficult to tell if it’s a legitimate request or a potential scam.

BEC is particularly effective since it does not contain a malicious link or attachment which might trigger anti-spam or antivirus software to block it. From 2013-2015 alone, it is estimated that BEC scams cost both small and large businesses 3.1 billion USD.

Defend Yourself

Against BEC

To defend yourself against BECs, follow these best practices:
Call the executive or manager to verify that the request is legitimate.
Double-check the email address of the sender to make sure it isn’t being spoofed.
Avoid replying to the sender, especially if this is being received from a personal email address. Instead, forward your response to the executive or manager’s actual work email address.
Be wary of changes in how the sender communicates, especially if you are asked to maintain secrecy or if the tone is urgent.
If you do fall victim to a BEC, it is very important to alert your manager quickly. If funds were transferred, there may be a chance to freeze the process and recover the funds.

Online Scams

Phishing is one popular way for online scammers to steal your identity. But unfortunately, that is not the only way they may try to rob you.

Social media accounts can be hijacked or exploited by a cybercriminal who may try to scam you with fake pleas for assistance or donations, or send you infected links with “fake news” articles.

They’ll also “poison” search results with infected websites for popular subjects or significant media events, such as a celebrity’s death, a natural disaster, or elections. When big news hits, stick with well-known news sites to avoid these scams.

Phishing Interactivity
From: "Energy Billing System" <PowerSystems@ymail.com>
Energy Statement
Dear Customer,
Your latest energy bill is now available for view online.

Account Number: 00937409287
Total Amount Due (Past Due): $1,224.30

To view your most recent bill, please click here. You must log-in to your account or register for an online account to view your statement. There are many options to pay your bill. Sign up for the Automatic Payment Plan to have your payment automatically deducted from your bank or credit card. Pay electronically online at the Account Center, visit an Authorized Payment Center or send a check by mail. Our monthly bill gives you energy-saving tips, regulatory updates and more.

LATE PATMENT WARNING
Please be advised that your account is past due. If payment is not received immediately, your utility services may be disconnected without further warning.
0
of 5 Items found
The return email address is not from the power company.
The message is not customized with your name.
The email contains information designed to elicit an emotional response and immediate action.

http://www.server01.myhost.com/PowerSystems

On hovering over the link, you see that it does not go to the URL of the company that supposedly sent it.
A threat is used to encourage you to act immediately. Also, obvious misspellings are a common sign of a phishing attempt.

Simulation:

Phishing

Click on each item that looks suspicious.

Note: iPad and Android users should touch each item twice.

Interactivity Complete

This example is based on an actual phishing email. Anyone who clicked on the “click here” link was exposed to malware that could secretly take control of their computer, which goes to show why it’s so important to always think before you click.

Mail App
From: Lucas.Anderson@InvestorsInc.com
YourInfo.zip
6 / 16 / 2017
Health Benefits
Hi Alexis,

Your manager asked me to send you this benefits report to give you an idea about changes to our health plan.
You can also see it by opening the attached zip file. The password for the zip file is Xip2@32M.

Regards, Lucas

Simulation

Lucas Anderson works at your organization, Investors Inc, in Human Resources. Is receiving an email from him suspicious?
Lucas Anderson works at your organization, Investors Inc, in Human Resources. Is receiving an email from him suspicious?
Yes
No
Yes
No
Please Try Again.

Correct.
Interactivity Complete.

Simulation:

Spear Phishing

Identify which parts of this email seem suspicious.

Mail App
From: Lucas.Anderson@InvestorsInc.com
YourInfo.zip
6 / 16 / 2017
Health Benefits
Hi Alexis,

Your manager asked me to send you this benefits report to give you an idea about changes to our health plan.
You can also see it by opening the attached zip file. The password for the zip file is Xip2@32M.

Regards, Lucas

Simulation

The email also contains an attached zip file that is protected with a password, but the password is included in the message. Is that suspicious?
The email also contains an attached zip file that is protected with a password, but the password is included in the message. Is that suspicious?
Yes
No
Yes
No
Please Try Again.

Correct.
Email-based virus scanners can’t open or scan password protected zip files, so spear phishers love sending malicious software this way. Interactivity Complete.

Mail App
From: Lucas.Anderson@InvestorsInc.com
YourInfo.doc
6 / 16 / 2017
Health Benefits
Hi Alexis,

Your manager asked me to send you this benefits report to give you an idea about changes to our health plan.
You can also see it by opening the attached doc file. The password for the doc file is Xip2@32M.

Regards, Lucas

Simulation

What if Lucas had sent a Word document instead. Could this be suspicious?
What if Lucas had sent a Word document instead. Could this be suspicious?
Yes
No
Yes
No
Please Try Again.

Correct.
Even Microsoft Office documents can contain malicious code. Typically, this would be embedded within a macro and the document would require you to enable macros in order to view the text. In general, it is best to disable macros if they are not needed. Interactivity Complete.
Your Responsibilities
Internet
Email and Instant Messages (IM)
Social Media
Other Prohibited Activities

Interactivity:

Acceptable Use Policies

In addition to the best practices mentioned so far, we also have a set of acceptable use policies that are designed to ensure both security and efficiency within our organization.

Click each item to learn more.
Workplace Privacy: Please also be aware that our internal workplace infrastructure is monitored for abuse.

Your Responsibilities

As a computer end-user, you are expected to use information resources in a responsible and legal manner for work related purposes, demonstrating respect for security, ethics and privacy policies, intellectual property rights, and every individual’s right to freedom from intimidation and harassment.

Close

Internet

Access to the Internet is provided to help you work more efficiently. While limited personal use of the Internet is allowed, use of the Internet must NOT :

  • Interfere with your work.
  • Involve obscene, sexually explicit, threatening, or illegal activity.
  • Violate any policies or laws.
  • Consume excessive time or resources.

Close

Email and Instant Messages (IM)

Email and Instant Messaging should NOT be used for the following:

  • Excessive personal communications.
  • Transmission or retransmission of inappropriate content.
  • Personal business or solicitation.
  • Unauthorized transmission of sensitive information.

Close

Social Media

If you access social media sites, follow these best practices to maximize security:

  • Do not post personal information that could be used by identity thieves, such as your phone number, birthday, etc.
  • Only allow “friends” to view your profile or posts or send you messages.
  • Do not accept friend invitations from those you do not know.
  • Turn on available security features, such as SSL encryption and logon alerts.

Close

Other Prohibited Activities

Other prohibited activities include:

  • Making, installing, or sharing illegal or pirated copies of software.
  • Attempting to access secure data or resources without authorization.

Close

Page.Name: Question 8

Elements.Intro:
Challenge

Questions

To apply what you've learned so far, please answer the following question.

Note: iPad and Android users should touch each item twice
Elements.Element:
Question 8 of 12

Challenge Question

Which of the following do you think is allowed by our acceptable use policies?

Options.Option: Web-loafing: Excessive surfing of the web while at work.
A quick phone call to your spouse to coordinate childcare or some other activity.
Sending email messages with obscene, sexually explicit, or threatening content.

Page.Answer: Please try again.

Correct

Limited personal use of company resources, such as phones is permitted.

CONTINUE
Please try again.

Stage.Element: Badges
Gates, Doors, & Exits
Visitors

Interactivity:

Entry Controls

Without physical security, none of our information can be secured, which is why we’ve deployed entry controls at our facilities. Click each item to learn more about entry control best practices.

Badges

  • Never leave your ID badge or access card unguarded. It should be worn or with you at all times and never lent out.
  • If you lose your ID badge or access card, report it immediately.
  • If you see someone without an ID badge or visitor’s badge, politely escort the person to the security desk for sign in or report it to security personnel right away.

Close

Gates, Doors, and Exits

  • Don’t allow others to gain entrance to a secure location or restricted zone without using their own badge, access card, or key code, a practice known as tailgating or piggy-backing.
  • Never leave doors to sensitive locations open or unlocked.
  • Always be aware of the nearest emergency exit to your workspace.

Close

Visitors

  • Visitors should be checked in, escorted at all times, always wear a visitor badge, and return their visitor badge before leaving.
  • Visitors should not be allowed to use cameras or recording equipment of any kind without special permission.
  • If a visitor requests Internet access, ensure he or she is only given limited guest access.

Close
Copiers and Printers
Clear Your Desk
Shared Meeting Areas

Interactivity:

Secure Work Areas

Entry control has to do with external threats. But what about internal threats from malicious insiders, employees, or others with legitimate access to our facilities who may be out to steal from or otherwise do harm to our organization?
Click each item to learn about best practices to protect against the malicious insider threat.

Copiers and Printers

Did you know modern copiers and printers have hard drives, just like your computer, and store every document ever copied or printed? Ensure the data on these hard drives is digitally wiped clean before the devices are disposed of.

Close

Clear Your Desk

While away from your desk:

  • Make sure all papers, removable media, and other items containing sensitive information are cleared from your desk and locked away.
  • Logoff of or lock your computer to ensure it cannot be accessed by anyone while you are away.
A password protected screensaver can be used to automatically lock your computer after a certain period of inactivity.

Close

Shared Meeting Areas

Shared meeting areas should also be kept free of sensitive information. When you leave a meeting area, be sure to erase any whiteboards, take all documents with you, and be careful what you throw in the trash.

Close
Clear Desk Simulation
of 4 items found
0
1
2
3
4
Sensitive documents left in unlocked drawer.
Sensitive documents left in unlocked drawer.
Computer left logged on while user is away from the desk.
Computer left logged on while user is away from the desk.
Password written on a note.
Password written on a note.
ID Badge left on desk.
ID Badge left on desk.

Simulation:

Clear Desk

Click on each item that violates a best practice.

Note: iPad and Android users should touch each item twice.

Interactivity Complete

Please click the red "Close" button, then click "Next" below to continue.
Confidential
Sensitive (Internal Use Only)
Public

Interactivity:

Data Classifications

Ensuring data is safeguarded is a critical aspect of information security and an area where you can make a big difference. The best practices you should apply depend on the class of data you are dealing with. Click each folder to learn more about data classifications.

Confidential

Confidential data is data whose loss, corruption, or unauthorized disclosure would violate laws, regulations, or contracts and possibly damage our reputation. Examples include private healthcare, financial, or any other data that may be protected by privacy laws, trade secrets, proprietary data, and strategic plans.

Close

Sensitive: Internal Use Only

All data not considered confidential, but also not approved for public use is considered sensitive. Sensitive data is data whose loss would inconvenience our organization but not cause financial harm or harm to our reputation. Examples include reports, schedules, or email messages free of confidential information.

Close

Public

Public data is data that has been approved for public use, for example, annual reports, website content, and press releases.

Close

Page.Name: Interactivity: Data Storage and Transmission Best Practices

Stage.Element: Confidential
Sensitive (Internal Use Only)
Public

Interactivity: Data Storage and

Transmission Best Practices

Now that you have a better understanding of data classifications, let’s review best practices for each type. Click each folder to learn more.

Backups: In addition to preventing unauthorized access, securing information means ensuring it is not lost. Always save files to a location that you know is regularly backed up, such as a network or "home" directory.

Confidential

Confidential data should be:

  • Marked “Confidential.”
  • Have a limited, need to know distribution.
  • Be protected with advanced security when being stored including access control lists, passwords, and encryption for electronic data and locked storage areas for hardcopy data.
  • Be encrypted when being transmitted with an approved encryption system, such as secure email, secure http, or secure ftp.

Close

Sensitive: Internal Use Only

Sensitive data should be:

  • Marked “Sensitive”.
  • Have a limited, need to know distribution.
  • Be protected when being stored with access control lists and passwords.
Sensitive information does not require encryption for storage or transmission.

Close

Public

Public data does not require any special security precautions.

Close

Data Retention &

Disposal Best Practices

Certain types of data such as contracts and company policies must be retained for a set, legally required period of time. Please review our Data Retention Policy(ies) for additional information.

Believe it or not, people will go through our garbage looking for confidential and sensitive information. That’s why we must properly dispose of those types of data by shredding or incinerating hardcopy files before disposing of them and physically destroying or wiping out all data on desktops, laptops, and removable media (e.g., USB drives, Micro SD cards, or hard drives, etc.) before disposing of them.

On the other hand, there are no special requirements for disposing of public data.

Using Public

Cloud Storage

Storing sensitive workplace information on public cloud storage services (e.g. iCloud or Google Drive) poses a serious security threat, because it places information outside of our organization’s control. And if the cloud storage service is hacked, which is not uncommon, the sensitive information could be exposed. This could violate policy, contractual obligations, and the law.

For optimum security, only use approved secure cloud storage services.

Page.Name: Question 9

Elements.Intro:
Challenge

Questions

To apply what you've learned so far, please answer the following questions.

Note: iPad and Android users should touch each item twice
Elements.Element:
Question 9 of 12

Challenge Question

Which of the following do you think is true or false?

Confidential data must be encrypted while it is stored or transmitted and always password protected.

Options.Option: True
False

Page.Answer:
Correct

Confidential data must be protected by these advanced security measures.

CONTINUE
Please try again.

Page.Name: Question 10

Elements.Element:
Question 10 of 12

Challenge Question

Any information that is not considered confidential can be shared with the public.

Options.Option: True
False

Page.Answer: Please try again.

Correct

Any data not considered confidential is considered sensitive and for internal use only. Only data explicitly approved for public use can be shared with the public.

CONTINUE

Module.Name: Mobile and Remote Computing Best Practices

Stage.Element:
Protecting

Mobile Data and Devices

Taking workplace information with you can help you be much more efficient while away from the workplace and is sometimes necessary to get the job done.

However, doing so exposes our organization to the risk of losing data, or worse, exposing confidential data to the public, which could violate laws and lead to a public relations nightmare.

Page.Name: Interactivity: Protecting Mobile Data and Devices

Stage.Element: All Mobile Data Devices
Hardcopy Files
Smartphones and Tablets

Interactivity: Protecting

Mobile Data and Devices

Before removing workplace data from our facilities, you should get supervisor permission. To learn more about additional best practices you should follow, click each item below.

All Mobile Data Devices

  • Only place workplace information on a mobile device if it is absolutely necessary and the device can protect it.
  • Remove workplace information when it is no longer needed.
  • If you must store workplace information on a mobile device, encrypt the data.
  • Use a strong password on all mobile devices.

Close

Hardcopy Files

Properly dispose of any sensitive or confidential information in hardcopy format that you remove from the workplace based on our security policy.

Close

Smartphones and Tablets

  • Ensure your mobile operating system is up to date with the latest software updates.
  • Report a lost device that contains or can access workplace information immediately. Some workplace information, such as email can be disabled and data on the device can also be wiped remotely.
  • Only use trusted, regulated app stores.
  • Never “jail-break” an iPhone or “root” an Android phone, since that turns off security features.

Close

The "Internet of Things"

(IoT)

Did you know that it is projected that by 2025, there will be over 75 billion “things” connected to the Internet? These things include web-enabled security cameras, thermostats, door locks, Smart TVs, health monitors, light bulbs, and countless other devices.

Such massive connectivity could make life much more convenient for you but potentially for criminals as well. It’s not hard to imagine what a criminal could do if he or she could see inside your house using your own monitoring system and then unlock the doors remotely.

Example: Unsecured IoT Device Exposed to the Public
Recently, Spiral Toys, a maker of Internet connected stuffed animals, leaked voice recordings, email addresses, and passwords. This was due to lax security allowing for a database to be made public, compromising over 800,000 accounts.

Best Practices:

For IoT Devices

IoT devices have flooded the market over the past few years, and the race to meet demand while offering competitive prices often means that these devices have a fraction of the security provided with a laptop or desktop computer. Follow these best practices to help stay secure:
Before attempting to connect any device to our organization’s network, you should always get approval first.
When shopping for IoT devices, only buy from trusted brands.
After you set up the device, change the default username and password.
Make sure the device receives automatic software and firmware updates.
Make sure network communications with the device can be encrypted.
Turn off any unneeded connections, such as Bluetooth and NFC. And, if you don’t need the device to access the Internet, don’t connect it to your network.

Page.Name: Working in Public Places: Best Practices

Stage.Element:
Best Practices:

Working in Public Places

Working in public places can help you be more efficient, but also exposes us to additional risks. Please follow these best practices when working in public places:
Never discuss confidential information in public places. You never know who could be listening in.
Be careful when displaying workplace information on your screen in public places. Someone could be reading it over your shoulder (shoulder surfing).

Only use encrypted Wi-Fi Internet connections. Be aware that cybercriminals will often mimic a legitimate wireless network, such as at a hotel or airport with one that looks very similar. Make sure that if you do need to access one of these networks, that the name is accurate.
Never leave mobile data devices in view where they could lure thieves.

Best Practices:

Remote Access

Working remotely, for example from your home, is another situation in which you may have to remove data from the workplace and therefore requires special precautions.

Please keep the following in mind:
The same security policies and standards apply when working remotely as in the workplace.
Any computer used to remotely access the network must be approved, secured with antivirus and antispyware software and a personal firewall, and meet all other minimum security requirements.
Remote access to the workplace network must be over a VPN connection, which secures all communications.
Travel Safety

Interactivity:

Travel Safety

When traveling to another city or country, the same best practices apply for protecting information you take with you. However, additional personal safety best practices should also be followed.

If you go on business trips, please click on the Travel Safety button below to learn more about protecting yourself while traveling.

Travel Safety: Best Practices

Itinerary: Leave a complete itinerary and copies of important documents, like your ID and passport, with someone and check in with that person periodically.

Luggage Tags: Ensure your luggage is tagged with your name, address, and phone number and not left unattended.

Transporting Items: Do not transport items for others.

Business Gifts: Be cautious with business gifts received overseas before returning home with them.

Taxis: Only use registered taxi services and be sure you are dropped off at a safe, well-lit place. Travel with a trusted colleague or companion if possible if in an unfamiliar locale.

Airport Rides: If you are being picked up at the airport, verify the identity of the driver before getting in the car.

Displays of Wealth: Avoid taking or displaying expensive equipment or jewelry.

Credit Cards: Only take the credit cards and money that you need for the trip.

Hotel Safe: Lock expensive items and a backup credit card in your hotel safe.

Close

Page.Name: Question 11

Elements.Intro:
Challenge

Questions

To apply what you've learned so far, please answer the following questions.

Note: iPad and Android users should touch each item twice
Elements.Element:
Question 11 of 12

Challenge Question

Which of the following is a TRUE statement about mobile computing?

Options.Option: You should report a lost or stolen mobile device within one week of the device going lost.
If your device contains workplace information, never connect it to an unsecured wireless connection.
You do not need prior approval to store confidential information as long as you’re using your own mobile device.
Only download software updates for mobile devices when it is absolutely necessary, no more than quarterly.

Page.Answer: Please try again.

Correct

Attackers can more easily gain access to confidential data through unsecured wireless networks.

CONTINUE
Please try again.
Please try again.

Page.Name: Question 12

Elements.Element:
Question 12 of 12

Challenge Question

You download an app to your tablet that gives you access to thousands of free apps. Should you download and install these apps?

Options.Option: Yes
No

Page.Answer: Please try again.

Correct

Unofficial app stores that offer free versions of popular, priced apps are typically full of “repackaged apps” which are versions of the apps that have been hacked to contain malware. You should only use trusted app stores, such as Google Play or Apple’s App Store.

CONTINUE

Stage.Element:
Summary

Securing our information resources is vital to our success and cannot be achieved without your help.

We’re counting on you to put the best practices outlined in this course to use immediately to secure our information and help ensure privacy.

Incident Response

We’re also depending on you to report any security incidents you are aware of so that we can improve the overall security, performance, and reliability of the network.

An information security incident is a violation or imminent threat of violation of security policies, acceptable use policies, or standard security practices. Please report any security incidents immediately.

Security

Policy Acceptance

Our Information Security Policy(ies) can be accessed by clicking on the following link(s):

A link to your Information Security Policy

It is the responsibility of each employee to read, understand and follow the policy standards, guidelines, processes, and procedures set forth in the Information Security Policy(ies). Please take a moment to review this policy(ies) before proceeding to the policy acceptance form on the next page.

Page.Name: Security Policy Acceptance Form
Page.IncompleteBox: You must accept our information security policy(ies) to complete this course and receive credit.
Page.SuccessBox: Thank you for accepting our Information Security Policy(ies).
Page.InvalidBox: You must accept our information security policy(ies) to complete this course and receive credit.

Elements.Element: Security Policy Acceptance Form
Please click "I Accept" below if you agree with this statement.

Policy

I hereby acknowledge that I have read, or shall read, understand, and agree to follow the standards, guidelines, best practices, processes, and procedures set forth in the Information Security Policy(ies). I understand that failure to comply with this policy(ies) can lead to disciplinary action, up to termination of employment.
SUBMIT

Content

Section Complete

You have completed the content section of this course. You can now review the material or go directly to the final exam. The exam questions focus on what users can do to help make the network more secure.

Course Complete
